The visual style of *The Economist* is instantly recognizable: the light blue-gray background, the clean horizontal grid lines, and the bold red tag in the top left. In this post, I will show you how to recreate this professional look using R and `ggplot2`.

We will use the `ggthemes` package, which provides a ready-made `theme_economist()`.

First, let's load the necessary libraries.

```r
# 加载必要的包
# Load necessary packages
library(ggplot2)
library(ggthemes)
library(dplyr)
```

## 1. Line Chart: Economic Trends (折线图)

Line charts are perfect for time series data. We use the built-in `economics` dataset.

```r
# 1. 准备数据：计算个人储蓄率
# Prepare data: calculate personal savings rate
data(economics)

# 2. 绘制折线图
# Create line chart
p1 <- ggplot(economics, aes(x = date, y = psavert)) +
  geom_line(color = "#014d64", size = 1) +  # 使用 Economist 风格的深蓝色 (Use Economist dark blue)
  labs(
    title = "Personal Savings Rate",        # 标题 (Title)
    subtitle = "US economics data",         # 副标题 (Subtitle)
    y = "Savings Rate (%)",                 # Y轴标签 (Y-axis label)
    x = "",                                 # X轴留空 (Leave X-axis blank)
    caption = "Source: ggplot2 economics"   # 数据来源 (Data source)
  ) +
  theme_economist() +                       # 应用 Economist 主题 (Apply Economist theme)
  scale_color_economist()                   # 应用颜色标尺 (Apply color scale)

# 显示图表
# Show chart
p1
```

## 2. Bar Chart: Ranking Cars (柱状图)

For ranking or comparing categories, a horizontal bar chart works best. Let's look at the `mtcars` dataset.

```r
# 1. 准备数据：按马力(hp)选取前10辆车
# Prepare data: select top 10 cars by horsepower
df_bar <- mtcars %>%
  tibble::rownames_to_column("car") %>%
  arrange(desc(hp)) %>%
  slice(1:10)

# 2. 绘制柱状图
# Create bar chart
p2 <- ggplot(df_bar, aes(x = reorder(car, hp), y = hp)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#014d64") +              # 使用 Economist 深蓝色填充 (Fill with Economist dark blue)
  coord_flip() +                            # 翻转坐标轴变成条形图 (Flip coordinates for horizontal bars)
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 Powerful Cars",         # 标题
    subtitle = "Horsepower (hp) by model",  # 副标题
    y = "Horsepower",                       # Y轴
    x = "",                                 # X轴
    caption = "Source: mtcars dataset"      # 来源
  ) +
  theme_economist(horizontal = FALSE) +     # horizontal=FALSE 让网格线适应翻转后的坐标 (Adjust grid for flipped coords)
  theme(
    axis.text.y = element_text(hjust = 0)   # 左对齐 Y 轴文字 (Left-align Y-axis text)
  )

# 显示图表
p2
```

## 3. Scatter Plot: Correlation (散点图)

Scatter plots show relationships. We will use the `iris` dataset to see the relationship between sepal length and width.

```r
# 绘制散点图
# Create scatter plot
p3 <- ggplot(iris, aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, color = Species)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +       # 点的大小和透明度 (Point size and opacity)
  labs(
    title = "Iris Sepal Dimensions",        # 标题
    subtitle = "Length vs Width by Species",# 副标题
    x = "Sepal Length",                     # X轴
    y = "Sepal Width",                      # Y轴
    caption = "Source: iris dataset"        # 来源
  ) +
  theme_economist() +                       # 应用主题
  scale_color_economist() +                 # 使用 Economist 调色板 (Use Economist color palette)
  theme(legend.position = "right")          # 图例放在右侧 (Legend on the right)

# 显示图表
p3
```

## Summary

Using `theme_economist()` allows us to instantly achieve a publication-quality look. The key elements are:
1.  **Background**: The signature blue-gray.
2.  **Grid**: White horizontal grid lines.
3.  **Typography**: Clean, professional fonts.

I hope this helps you create beautiful charts in R!
